awd_titl_txt: Investigating The Relationship Between Environment And Social Complexity
awd_abstract_narration:
The formation of complex societies - those with hierarchically organized social, political, and economic systems - is a watershed occurrence in general human cultural evolution. 10,000 years ago, everyone lived in egalitarian societies; today, almost everyone lives in a complex nation-state. With National Science Foundation support, Dr. Eric Jones will conduct archaeological research at Late Precontact (AD 1000-1600) sites in the southeastern United States to determine the landscape factors that influenced the formation of complex societies in this region. Examining the processes and circumstances surrounding how complexity was formed helps  to determine the long-term social, political, and economic trajectories that have created modern conditions. Although archaeologists have made great strides in understanding how and why this process occurs, they are still learning. In particular, the reasons why complex societies arose and persisted in specific locations has rarely been studied and is thus not well understood. It is an important topic, however, because it can reveal the historical and cultural processes that have shaped the last 10,000 years of human history with regard to complexity. Specifically, it can improve understanding of historic and modern human geography because the distribution of societies of varying complexity impacted Native American-European interactions during the colonial period. Further, it can provide information about human interactions with the environment in relation to varying complexity.

The Southeast, particularly the Piedmont, is an ideal area to study the spatial and landscape components of complexity because it was one of the few areas of North America occupied simultaneously by complex and non-complex societies. Furthermore, this area has a long history of archaeological research and detailed accounts from the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries. This three-year study will examine the environmental and cultural landscape features that influenced the patterning of societies of varying complexity. It will do this using a combination of archaeological excavation and survey, modeling of past landscapes using historical, geological, geographic, and environmental data, and geographic information systems (GIS)-based spatial analyses. The results will explain why some locations saw the development of social and political hierarchies and others did not. 

With regard to broader impacts, Dr. Jones' research will be one of the few projects to examine and compare the landscapes of non-hierarchical and hierarchical societies in North America. Understanding the origins of social hierarchies and related landscapes has the potential to inform about our own social structure, specifically with regards to interactions with the environment. Undergraduates will be involved in all levels of research, including archival work, fieldwork, artifact and spatial analyses, and the presentation and publication of results. Each year Dr. Jones and students will organize public archaeology events inviting students, local residents, and representatives from local Native American communities to engage in conversations about local history, the importance of cultural historic preservation, and Native American cultures and history. Information from this research will also be integrated into the Wake Forest Museum of Anthropology and will be made available as a digital database for other researchers.

por.por_cntn:
The creation of hierarchical and sociopolitically complex societies (i.e. composed of a high number of unequal social groupings and centralized political control) is one of the most important human cultural inventions. Along with agriculture, the creation of complex societies has had perhaps the greatest influence in shaping the modern world. Our first evidence of complex societies is approximately 7500 years ago. Understanding why they arose is important for understanding the impact hierarchical structures have on aspects of our lives, such as health, political relationships, gender roles, and economic systems. An important aspect of studying why complex societies arose is the geography and ecology of these societies. That is, why did they arise where they did? In addition, characterizing the interaction between complex societies and their neighbors can help us understand why complexity proliferated and the nature of human interaction across cultural and sociopolitical boundaries. This project examined these last two topics for egalitarian Piedmont Village Tradition (PVT) communities and adjacent complex Mississippian societies in Southeastern North America from 1000-1600 CE.

Geographic Information Systems-based landscape and environmental reconstructions were combined with settlement pattern data on multiple scales and analyzed using discriminant function analysis to determine what features correlated with PVT and Mississippian settlements. In general, the former were strongly influenced in their settlement location choice decisions by productive sediments in large floodplains along major rivers. However, communities nearer to cultural and political boundaries showed more influence by defensible locations. PVT communities living near larger and more complex Mississippian societies appear to have removed themselves from transportation networks. Those communities farther from boundaries focused more on food production and less on defensibility. Mississippian communities tended to form in diverse ecological landscapes with dense forests and near transportation network confluences. This supports theories on how Mississippian religious and political ideology mapped onto the political ideologies of local emerging elites through access to symbolically charged objects acquired through trade. This occurred in societies with larger populations, resulting from productive and diverse environments, where these elites could gather large groups of potential followers. The emergence of these new Mississippian elites, in turn, impacted neighboring PVT communities. Smaller scale analyses showed that PVT communities on the border with Mississippian societies initially migrated away from them after initial violent interactions around 1200 CE. During the next 300 years they maintained their economic connections to other PVT communities. Analysis of exotic lithic material and ceramic stylistic similarities between communities shows they maintained non-overlapping social and economic networks during this time. Previous assumptions that economic motives drove or correlated with social interactions for smaller egalitarian societies did not hold true. Around 1500 CE, PVT communities shifted economic interactions toward Mississippian neighbors. Over time, egalitarian societies may get drawn more toward the more complex neighbors for economic reasons. This work created a model for multi-scalar settlement ecology research to produce detailed descriptions of how communities interact with their natural and cultural surroundings.

This research supported research for 25 undergraduates in the field and laboratory. Over half of these students were women and just under a quarter were students of color, increasing diversity in archaeology. Each field season included public archaeology events that engaged with local communities in the Yadkin River Valley. The PI gave 10 public lectures in local communities. Results were also presented in 16 posters and talks at regional and national conferences. Findings were published in 7 peer-reviewed articles and book chapters, and this research was a significant contributor to a book co-edited by the PI. This work has significant benefits to society, as it helps us understand the origins of sociopolitical complexity and social hierarchies, how those societies interact with egalitarian societies, and possible reasons for why the last 7500 years of human culture has trended toward complex sociopolitical organizations.
